description: An edible green plant in the cabbage family whose large flowering head, stalk and small associated leaves are eaten as a vegetable.
healthBenefits: Rich in Vitamin C and K, supporting immune function and bone health.
Contains sulforaphane, a compound with potent anti-cancer properties and detoxification support.
Good source of fiber, aiding digestion and promoting gut health.
May help reduce cholesterol levels and support cardiovascular health.

potentialAllergies.name: Brassica Allergy
potentialAllergies.details: Rare, but can occur in individuals sensitive to cruciferous vegetables. Symptoms may include skin rash or digestive upset.

potentialAllergies.name: Goitrogens
potentialAllergies.details: Contains goitrogens, which may interfere with thyroid function in individuals with pre-existing thyroid conditions if consumed raw in very large amounts. Cooking typically reduces goitrogen levels.

cultivationProcess: Broccoli is a cool-season crop. Prefers well-drained, fertile soil rich in organic matter and full sun (at least 6 hours). Grown from seeds started indoors or direct-sown, or from transplants. Main heads are harvested when florets are tightly packed and dark green, before yellow flowers appear. Side shoots may develop after the main head is cut.
growthDuration: 50-100 days from transplant to harvest, depending on variety and conditions.
sustainabilityTips: Store unwashed broccoli in an open plastic bag in the refrigerator crisper for up to a week.
Utilize the stalks as well as the florets – peel the tough outer layer of stalks and slice; they are nutritious and can be cooked.
Blanch and freeze excess broccoli for longer storage to use in soups, stir-fries, or smoothies.
carbonFootprintInfo: Relatively low footprint when grown locally (0.4-0.7 kg CO2e/kg). Long-distance transport, especially refrigerated, increases this.

staticRecipes.name: Simple Steamed Broccoli
staticRecipes.description: A quick and healthy way to prepare broccoli, preserving its nutrients and vibrant color.
ingredients: 1 head of broccoli, cut into florets
steps: Place broccoli florets in a steamer basket over an inch of boiling water. Cover and steam for 3-5 minutes, until tender-crisp.
Alternatively, place florets in a microwave-safe dish with 1-2 tbsp of water. Cover and microwave on high for 2-4 minutes.
Season with salt and pepper. Squeeze fresh lemon juice over and drizzle with olive oil if desired.

staticRecipes.name: Broccoli Cheddar Soup
staticRecipes.description: A creamy and comforting soup packed with broccoli and cheesy goodness.
ingredients: 1 lb broccoli florets (fresh or frozen), roughly chopped
Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste
steps: Melt butter in a large pot or Dutch oven over medium heat. Add onion and cook until softened, about 5 minutes.
Add garlic and cook for 1 minute more. Stir in flour and cook, stirring, for 1 minute.
Gradually whisk in milk and broth until smooth. Bring to a simmer, stirring constantly.
Add broccoli florets. Cook for 10-15 minutes, or until broccoli is very tender.
Reduce heat to low. If desired, use an immersion blender to partially or fully blend the soup for a smoother texture.
Stir in shredded cheddar cheese until melted and smooth. Do not allow the soup to boil after adding cheese.
Season with salt and pepper. Serve hot.

staticRecipes.name: Garlic Roasted Broccoli with Parmesan
staticRecipes.description: Roasting broccoli brings out its nutty flavor, enhanced beautifully with garlic and Parmesan cheese.
ingredients: 2-3 cloves garlic, minced or thinly sliced
Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste
Red pepper flakes (optional, for a kick)
steps: On a large baking sheet, toss broccoli florets with olive oil, minced garlic, salt, pepper, and red pepper flakes (if using) until evenly coated.
Spread broccoli in a single layer to ensure even roasting.
Roast for 15-20 minutes, or until tender-crisp and lightly browned at the edges. Florets should be slightly charred.
Remove from oven, sprinkle immediately with grated Parmesan cheese, and toss gently.
